children.value: ≈Åowcy Niebios (los Cazadores del Cielo) es un juego de mesa creado por Gnoun en oto√±o de 2021.
Actualmente no copias de este juego existen y el original (en polaco) est√° quedando en la habitaci√≥n de Gnoun.

El juego es ambientado en alg√∫n lugar no especificado en el universo ficticio de Livuluria. Seg√∫n la introducci√≥n del juego, la partida empeza durante un tiempo dificil cuando se encuentra que los sombr√≠os fuerzas de Gindzuk est√°n capaz de destruir el sagrado templo de Eulidion, que es la √∫nica conexi√≥n de los Dioses a Livuluria. Despu√©s de que se difunde un mensaje pidiendo ayuda, m√∫ltiples clanes llegaron de varios esquinas del mundo, pero no est√°n necesariamente interesados en combatir los sombr√≠os fuerzas y en lugar de eso podr√≠an intentar a satisfacer sus propios necesitades.

Cada jugador es un l√≠der de su propio clan. Durante la partida, el jugador obtiene cartas y mejora sus estad√≠sticas para preparar a la √∫ltima batalla. El juego tiene una sistema de econom√≠a equilibrado que el jugador tiene que aprovechar para sobrevivir. Los jugadores tambi√©n est√°n constantemente desafiados por tanto las cartas de acciones que afectaton los jugadores individualmente como las cartas de acontecimiento que afectaron todos los jugarores y/o el mundo. Los jugadores no moven al azar ‚Äì tienen control total de la direcci√≥n en que van y la cantidad de campos que cruzaron, pero lo hacen a costa de su energ√≠a de clan. Tambi√©n se puede reclutar hasta 8 unidades, pero m√°s unidades significan menos energ√≠a libre para moverlos.

Los jugadores tienen una enorme cantidad de acciones a mano. Por ejemplo, pueden conquistar una ciudad para destruir la econom√≠a de otros jugadores y/o obtener estad√≠sticas y art√≠culos valiosos sin costo, o dirigirse al disierto de Reshaka o los Profundidades de Gluonor para un tresoro. Tambi√©n se espera que los jugadores compitan unos con otros, como su fuerza promedia influye en la fuerza de la fortaleza del enemigo. Una de las cosas principales por cual los jugadores pueden competir son las cinco Cartas de Cazadpres esparciendo por el mapa, que se puede combinar en dos maneras en conjuntos de tres para crear o un b√°culo poderoso que puede ayudar enormemente en destruir el enemigo o un art√≠culo que llama el Apocalipsis (uno de los tres variantes del final del juego).

Mientras hay muchas posibilidades, el juego tambi√©n tiene reglas que limitan a los jugadores para equilibrar la partida, como un limite de fuerza, y castigue a los jugadores para cruzar estos limites con las as√≠ llamadas cartas del Odio. Los jugadores tambi√©n pueden recibir cardas del Dioses, que tienen el efecto contrario, completando tareas dado por los Dioses.

A mitad de la partida, el clan del enemigo se unese a la partida y intenta a destruir el templo, los ciudades, y por √∫ltimo, los jugadores por s√≠. Si el templo se destruye, los jugadores no m√°s recibieren perjuicios por romper los limites del juego (como el limite de la fuerza), pero tambi√©n no fueren capaz de reaparecer despu√©s de perder todas sus unidades, haciendo la partida menos equilibrada. Si las ciudades se destruyen, las econom√≠as de los jugadores sufrieren mucho, llevando a menos oportunidades a reconstruir sus fuerzas despu√©s de choques. Tal final puede parecer tedioso, pero en realidad es muy agradable seg√∫n los que ya hab√≠an jugado el juego.
Generalmente hace falta alrededor de 8-15 horas (aproximadamente 40-60 turnos) para concluir una partida. Hasta ahora, nada partida se hab√≠a concluido dentro de un d√≠a.

El juego est√° destinado a 2-8 jugadores, pero seg√∫n las partidas ya realizadas, la jugabilidad es mejor con 3-4 (y quiz√°s 5) jugadores. Si la mayor√≠a de los jugadores est√°n nuevos en el juego, la jugabilidad puede ser tediosa y el juego se puede dejarse inacabado.
Gnoun tuvo tres influencias importantes durante la creaci√≥n el juego: su juego de mesa anterior "Wy≈õcig po Skarb" ("La Carrera para el Tesoro") de febrero 2018,

. "Wy≈õcig po Skarb" ya hab√≠a tenido cartas, aunque menor diferenciados, adem√°s de dos tiendas, areas especiales y tableros de jugadores, pero el movimiento todav√≠a era al azar. Conceptos tal que unidades m√∫ltiples, la fuerza del clan y las cartas del batalla eran mayoritariamente inspirados por Blood Rage. Tambi√©n era la inspiraci√≥n principal para el sistema de batalla. Tambi√©n podr√≠a influir la cronolog√≠a del juego. Aunque Gnoun mencione Monopoly entre sus inspiraciones importantes, es dificil decir cu√°les elementos del juego lo inspir√≥. Caracter√≠sticas como el sistema de econom√≠a y el concepto del clan de enemigo apareciendo como un jugador por s√≠ no eran inspirados por nada en particular y hab√≠an sido desarollando principalmente durante la producci√≥n.
Por primera vez, Gnoun hab√≠a pensado en el juego el primero de enero de 2021, despu√©s de jugar

con su familia. Despu√©s de eso, el 2-3 de enero de 2021, un partido de "Wy≈õcig po Skarb" se hab√≠a jugado, pero termin√≥ inconcluso. Despu√©s de descubrir muchos errores, Gnoun hab√≠a conseguido muchas ideas por el juego nuevo y empez√≥ a recogerlos. Con el tiempo, m√°s ideas se aparec√≠an, especialmente en marzo y abril. En abril, Gnoun ten√≠a suficiente ideas para considerar empezar el juego en julio, pero la producci√≥n hab√≠a sido finalmente retrasada a septiembre, en parte porque a unos de las caracteristicas les faltaba claridad y tambi√©n por la cantidad inesperada de proyectos desarrollados en julio.

La producci√≥n empez√≥ en 2 de septiembre y concluyo en 9 de diciembre. En temprano 2021, Gnoun lo esperaba a durar dos semanas, alrededor del doble que su juego anterior "Wy≈õcig po Skarb", y cuando la producci√≥n hab√≠a empezado, lo esperaba a terminar dentro del septiembre, pero resultaba que el juego era m√°s requiriendo. El tablero principal por s√≠ tom√≥ 2 semanas a completar. Resultaba que la instrucci√≥n ocupaba 20 p√°ginas, 6 de las cuales solamente describ√≠an acciones de los jugadores. Los 155 cartas tambi√©n resultaron llevar m√°s tiempo como cada contuvo un dise√±o detallado y finalmente llegaron a ser el m√°s requiriendo parte del juego. Tanto las cartas como la instrucci√≥n hab√≠an terminados solo a mediados de noviembre. Las fichas, sumando 271, se empezaban despu√©s de las cartas y tomaron alrededor de 2 semanas a completar. Por √∫ltimo, las tableros de clanes y las fichas representando unidades de jugadores se acumularon y el juego se termin√≥ decisivamente en 9 de diciembre.

El 11 de diciembre empez√≥ la primera partida de prueba, con BeetMacol y Myoko, jugando por 4 horas casi hasta la medianoche. En su "Trivia log", Gnoun mencion√≥ que el juego resultaba ser "muy equilibrado, pero un poco lento al principio (al menos para m√≠), posiblemente por nuestro falta de claras estrategias". La partida de prueba se concluy√≥ en 18 de diciembre. Gnoun mencion√≥ que tom√≥ "tres veces m√°s que esperado", aunque no se conoce que tiempo exactamente dur√≥ el juego. Gnoun probablemente expectaba que el juego dure 2-3 horas.

El 9 de enero de 2022, un mes despu√©s de la concluyera del producci√≥n, el juego recib√≥ una caja adeducada, que permiti√≥ a Gnoun a liberar espacio de su escritorio. Desde entonces, el juego est√° quedando sobre su guardarropa.

Initialmente, Gnoun dej√≥ el juego principalmente sin cambios aunque a unos caracteristicas menores les faltaban la claridad, y por lo menos una partida m√°s se hab√≠a estado jugando en 2022. El 6-7 enero de 2023, mientras de que Florik, un amigo de Cracovia, lleg√≥ a ≈Åomianki para quedarse por tres d√≠as hasta el 8 de enero, la primera partida completa de 4 jugadores se jug√≥ (con Gnoun, BeetMacol, Myoko y Florik participando), y result√≥ ser un perfectamente equilibrada partida y dur√≥ m√°s o menos 10 horas. Despu√©s de esa partida, Gnoun cre√≥ una lista de 15 cosas para considerar en el parche nuevo, que fue realizado en 26 de enero.

El 6-7 enero de 2023, mientras de que Florik, un amigo de Cracovia, lleg√≥ a ≈Åomianki para quedarse por tres d√≠as hasta el 8 de enero, la primera partida completa de 4 jugadores se jug√≥ (con Gnoun, BeetMacol, Myoko y Florik participando), y result√≥ ser un perfectamente equilibrada partida y dur√≥ m√°s o menos 10 horas. Despu√©s de esa partida, Gnoun cre√≥ una lista de 15 cosas para considerar en el parche nuevo, que fue realizado en 26 de enero. ### El Registro de Cambios #### 1.1.0 | 26 de enero de 2023 - La hidra: si el jugador tiene **menos** que x (7 ‚Äì la ca√±a de pescar, 5 ‚Äì el arp√≥n) fuerza, tira la unidad. (antes: si el jugador tiene **no m√°s** que x fuerza, tira la unidad) - Despu√©s de derrotar la ciudad, el jugador obtiene 1 fuerza. (antes: poco claro/0) - √âl primer jugador que alcanza Glendeyl tiene una acci√≥n de construir gratis. La ciudad tambi√©n empieza con 2 cartas de fuerza (en lugar de 1) - Para retener una carta despu√©s de una batalla, el ganador paga la cantidad de fuerza igual a `su fuerza de clan despu√©s de la batalla` por carta (antes: `4 - fuerza obtenido en la batalla`) - Durante el Fin de los Dioses, el clan de Gindzuk conquista cada ciudad **dividiendo su fuerzas en 2** - La tarjeta de acontecimiento "La Entrega de los Armas": si no hay suficiente cartas en la pila de fuerza, salta al pr√≥ximo acontecimiento - El "Cofre Secreto" no puede ser robado de una ciudad (antes: poco claro) - La carta "Paraguas" es de solo uso en Reshaka (antes: podr√≠a ser poco claro) - Los jugadores en la proximidad de x campos del campo de batalla pueden apoyar los luchadores a costa de x energ√≠a (antes: en la proximidad de 1 campo, a no costa) - Reducido Reshaka: 70 drenes -> 35 drenes, 35 drenes -> 10 drenes; el jugador move entre los premios a costa de 2 energ√≠a por campo con premio (antes: 1 energ√≠a) - Reducido el Clan de Vagabundos Desde Nada: empeza sin dinero - Reducido el "pidiendo a los dioses": si el jugador tiene no m√°s que 15 drenes y se encuentra no m√°s que 3 campos del templo, obtiene 10 drenes de los dioses (antes: no m√°s que 20 drenes; obtiene 15 drenes) #### 1.0.1 | ? (2022) - Para retener una carta despues de una batalla, el ganador paga la cantidad de fuerza igual a `4 - la fuerza conseguida en la batalla` per carta (antes: `la diferencia de fuerza en la batalla`) #### 1.0.0 | 9 de diciembre de 2021 - El juego se cre√≥. ### La galer√≠a Puede abrir los imagenes en una pesta√±a nueva para m√°s detalles.

_data.text:
#### Nueva actualizaci√≥n importante desde 1.5 a√±os!

Estoy feliz de anunciar que una nueva actualizaci√≥n llamado la Actualizaci√≥n Creativa es lanzada. He trabajado mucho durante la √∫ltima mitad del a√±o para lanzar esta actualizaci√≥n. Para los intereados, cre√≠ un p√°rrafo separado sobre lo que sucedi√≥ en 2022 y porque no hab√≠an nada actualizaci√≥n importante en ese a√±o.

La nueva actualizaci√≥n tiene mejor versiones de todos mis [composiciones m√∫sicales](music) tempranos y un poco de los nuevos. Todav√≠a no lanc√© mi m√∫sica de 2021, no pronto va a ser lanzada en una o otra manera. Tambi√©n he lanzado un poco de mis [cuentos](other/stories), no por ahora son disponible solo en polaco y por eso est√°n situando en la secci√≥n Otros. Tambi√©n a√±ad√≠ una descripci√≥n de mi juego de mesa [≈Åowcy Niebios](other/≈Çowcy-niebios), en que hab√≠a pasado la mayor parte de mi tiempo restante en 2021.

La actualzaci√≥n tambi√©n tiene dos nuevas traducciones (tan como una traducci√≥n experimental a mi conlang Daikova). Hab√≠a escribido todos completamente solo en su mayor√≠a en el verano de 2022 y luego ajust√©los despu√©s de lanzar la actualizacci√≥n. Si esta pregunt√°ndose porque no hay una traducci√≥n en, por ejemplo, la lengua ucraniana, es simplemente porque no conozco otros idiomas y no quiero crear traducciones de baja calidad. Por eso, no es probable que aparecer√°n traducciones nuevas, a menos que alguien cree su propia, confiable traducci√≥n del sitio completado por a solo.

#### Una otra actualizaci√≥n importante puede aparecir pronto

Si ha explorado minuciosamente la versi√≥n nueva, tambi√©n podr√≠a darse cuenta de que mi viejo art√≠culo sobre organizaci√≥n y planificaci√≥n ahora est√° archivado. Es porque recientemente empec√© a estudiar la direcci√≥n en la [Univerisdad de ≈Åazarski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lazarski_University) y encontr√© muchos elementos del art√≠culo irrelevantes. No voy a reescribir el art√≠culo, sin embargo informaci√≥n relevante va a ser incluido en mi nuevo proyecto que empezado en enero de 2022 que va a recibir su propia secci√≥n en el sitio en la Actualizaci√≥n de Informaci√≥n 5.0.

La actualizaci√≥n pr√≥xima dividir√° y ordenar√° a√∫n m√°s el sitio, a√±adiendo por lo menos dos secciones nuevas, y uniendo por lo menos otros dos. Su preparaci√≥n completa va a tomar m√°s que 500 horas (50% de que es completo por ahora), as√≠ que espero que la actualizaci√≥n va a ser lanzada en alg√∫n momento en verano de 2023.

#### Que sucedi√≥ en 2022?

Aunque no hubo nada actualizaci√≥n importante en 2022, era actualmente un a√±o muy ocupado.

En el compienzo del a√±o, me hab√≠a cuestado mucho mi universidad anterior, que finalmente dej√≥ (result√≥ que era una decisi√≥n muy buena). Mientras tanto, hab√≠a empezado trabajar en muchas cosas que van a aparecer en 5.0 o m√°s tarde. Es porque en este tiempo no ten√≠a una imagen completo de la pr√≥xima actualizaci√≥n importante. En la primavera, hab√≠a reunido una buen calidad de recursos m√∫sicales necesarios para componer mejor m√∫sica. Tambi√©n hab√≠a pasado mucho tiempo trabajando en mis habilidades de idiomas y de piano, de los cuales primero us√© en julio, cuando empec√© trabajar en 4.0. Alrededor el mismo tiempo, finalmente empec√© trabajar en mejorar mi m√∫sica y decidi incluir eso en la actualizaci√≥n tambi√©n. M√°s temprano, tambi√©n intentaba a volver a las matem√°ticas, pero eso era posible solo para cuando entr√© en mi universidad nueva. Mis habilidades de programaci√≥n no hab√≠an estado usados en 2022, sin embargo voy a regresar a programaci√≥n en la primavera cuando me presentaron a Python en la universidad. Por eso, 5.0 tambi√©n puede tener unos cambios en el c√≥digo.

Por lo tanto, ese a√±o aparecer√°n muchas cosas.

Oplysek CARTESIAN COORDINATES [mehkeli COORDINATEStar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_coordinate_system), gnak vystrek hukjik gavumek (evaluate) RADIUS *r* jon akur *Œ∏*. RADIUS sysek (IS THE SAME AS) orynus ulur, kes gnak miki swortvek [orynus ulur](magnitude) shlobun burjekoson. Burjekson *Œ∏*, gnak unwek akur setas TANGENT sysek *y* huklani *x*-yska.

Oplysekson mekheli COORDINATES CARTESIANtar, namkeku *x*-, *y*-, jon *r*-orta camakswi RIGHT farnakurtas, seskja *r* soek HYPOTENUSE. Sworteku don'k farnakriwekrani FUNCTIONS, COSINE jon SINE, skazedekson VALUES *x*- jon *y*-tas RESPECTIVELY.

*Cami NOTE: Konu hejon igzek swortveko hurik oplyskitswi.*

children.value:
I‚Äôve decided to write an ‚Äúarticle‚Äù on how I personally deal with organizing and planning my activities. I came up with this system by myself, so it might not work for everyone, yet I still decided to write about it. I hope someone finds this useful.
It‚Äôs quite a flexible concept, so you don‚Äôt have to apply everything at once to make it work. Feel free to take inspiration from this article.
Before we begin, I‚Äôve got to mention I came up with an entire terminology for this and I‚Äôll move from one term to another step-by-step.

The idea is that I divide life into a few ‚Äúthreads‚Äù which act as groups of certain activities. By activities, I mean repeatedly performed actions (such as playing a game, reading a book, or working on a project), but not habits we do automatically. In fact, Threads are categories of activities. Deciding what categories should these be is up to you; I have one thread for team projects, one for private projects, one for self-learning and one for playing games; occasionally some other appear from time to time.

Thread branches are simply the activities I talked about above. In a specific moment, each thread has a specific number of branches. It changes over time, and I log the changes in the so-called Threads Chronology.
A branch is considered to have joined a thread when a certain activity was started being performed and it is considered to have left on the day the activity was stopped being performed. I also call them active and inactive branches.
Apart from being active or inactive, a thread or branch can also be disabled, which means that it has been put in a state where nothing can be performed regarding it.

Stability is a concept I‚Äôve came up with much later and it isn‚Äôt as concrete. It‚Äôs a way of saying how far a thread or branch is from being inactive with respect to how often branches are planned to be performed but aren‚Äôt. An unstable thread or branch is closer to being inactive while a highly stable one means that the thread is prospering.
Stability is not measured precisely, although in fact doing so would be possible.

Each thread has its own influence regarding other threads. It is not measured by the number of branches a thread has; influence is a mixture of how often (approximately) a thread‚Äôs branches are performed and how important they are. It is in high portion the thread influence that I use to divide the timeline.

That‚Äôs how I called the time unit that bases mostly on thread influence. Basically, a period begins anytime a thread changes its position among other threads regarding their influence. For me, periods usually last about 1-3 weeks. I also name each of them and list them in the so-called Periods Chronology.
Recently, I‚Äôve started listing a small number of resolutions for each period. When it is obvious that most resolutions will fail, a period may be abandoned and a new one is started immediately.
Periods can also change regarding other events in the timeline which do or don‚Äôt affect thread branches‚Äô accessibility, such as a trip.

Acts are the most important of all time units. Each has its own name and a list of resolutions, which (for me) number between ten and twenty. Every act consists of multiple periods. Thus, periods are lower in the hierarchy and their resolutions have to be fairly close to those of the acts.
Unlike periods, acts are a bit more neutral regarding threads, although it is often the case that an act has a ‚Äúleading thread‚Äù. Even so, periods don‚Äôt always have the act‚Äôs leading thread as their own leading thread despite being subordinate to acts.
For me, acts often last about 5-8 months.

I never really plan when they are supposed to end (although I often make approximations); I often decide to start one (or prepare to start one) once there is a visible result of how well were the resolutions performed.

The third and most basic unit of time in my planning system is a single day. Each day has its own plan (or summary, if a plan wasn‚Äôt prepared), which consists of about 5-10 tasks. Most of the tasks concern thread branches, but obviously other tasks appear as well if they are necessary.
Alternative choice task ‚Äì a task that offers an alternative task which can be chosen to do instead. Sometimes there can be two as well, in this case one of the three has to be chosen;
Prior task ‚Äì a task that has to be completed regardless of anything;
‚ÄúIf possible‚Äù task ‚Äì in other words, a task that has to be complete only if there is more time;
Bonus task ‚Äì if all tasks are completed, there is a bonus task.
Sometimes tasks have time limits, although it‚Äôs not appropriate for every task. I‚Äôve got two ways of making time limits:
Absolute ‚Äì demands a task to be complete until a certain moment during the day;
Relative ‚Äì demands a task to be complete within a certain amount of time.
Recently, I‚Äôve added a bunch of new features to the planning system. Once a day is near its end, I write a short evaluation of the plan‚Äôs results and I rate my performance.
And, basically, that‚Äôs it. If you want, you can move further and read about how the system gradually formed in my mind.
This part may be less interesting for you as it mainly talks about how I ended up having this system and using Trello for applying the concept.

My first attempts to organize my time happened in 2018. On the last day of 2017, I‚Äôd created a list of 15 resolutions which I‚Äôd try to accomplish throughout 2018. I called them the New Year‚Äôs Eve Declaration. In early 2018 I‚Äôd come up with the idea of acts and named the first act as above.
Originally, I had a different system of organization. On January 3rd, upon my return from Masuria where I‚Äôve spent New Year‚Äôs Eve, I created the so-called Activity Log which would be the first log I‚Äôd use to track my progress throughout time. It relied on special rules upon which I had to accomplish tasks to gain points while I had to gain at least 1 point daily.

That system lasted over a year without much of a change, however in early 2019 I‚Äôve encountered more and more types of tasks that couldn‚Äôt be measured so easily ‚Äì for example, if 1 hour of learning a piano piece is worth one point, how much points would making a music piece be worth? It was March 2019 when my current system started taking a form.

In May 2018, I‚Äôve installed ColorNote and it served as the first app I used for organization. On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of.

In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later.

Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed.

Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing.

Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization.

Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board.
Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.

On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of. In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later. Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed. Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing. Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization. Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board. Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.

_data.name: Complex Division (polar form)

children.value: Dividing complex numbers in polar form is a bit easier than in rectangular form. The magnitudes can be divided separately from the rest of the number. The arguments of the cosine and sine functions can be subtracted from one another (click on the link below to see why).

_data.text: Dividing complex numbers in polar form is a bit easier than in rectangular form. The magnitudes can be divided separately from the rest of the number. The arguments of the cosine and sine functions can be subtracted from one another (click on the link below to see why).

_data.name: Complex Division (rectangular form)

children.value: Complex division is more difficult than addition, subtraction or multiplication (hence I made this tool). To divide two complex numbers in rectangular form, you need to multiply the number in the denominator by its
. To keep the same value, you also need to multiply the numerator. After a bit of simplyfing, you get the result.

_data.text: Complex division is more difficult than addition, subtraction or multiplication (hence I made this tool). To divide two complex numbers in rectangular form, you need to multiply the number in the denominator by its [complex conjugate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_conjugate). To keep the same value, you also need to multiply the numerator. After a bit of simplyfing, you get the result.

_data.name: Complex Number Polar to Rectangular Form Converter

children.value: To convert a complex number from polar to rectangular form, use the properties of a right triangle created from the x & y coordinates and the magnitude. Namely, apply the definition of cosine to find x, and same with sine and y.

_data.text: To convert a complex number from polar to rectangular form, use the properties of a right triangle created from the x & y coordinates and the magnitude. Namely, apply the definition of cosine to find x, and same with sine and y.

_data.name: Complex Number Rectangular to Polar Form Converter

children.value: To convert a complex number from rectangular form to polar form, we need to find the magnitude and angle of the complex number. To find the magnitude, apply the Pythagorean theorem (for complex number z = a + bi and magnitude r, r
). To find the angle, apply the tangent function (tan Œ∏ = b/a).

_data.text: To convert a complex number from rectangular form to polar form, we need to find the magnitude and angle of the complex number. To find the magnitude, apply the Pythagorean theorem (for complex number z = a + bi and magnitude r, r<sup>2</sup> = a<sup>2</sup> + b<sup>2</sup>). To find the angle, apply the tangent function (tan Œ∏ = b/a).

_data.name: Degree to Radian Converter

children.value: Radians are a different way to measure angles based on the circle's perimeter - 360 degrees are equal to 2œÄ radians. To convert degrees to radians, all you have to do is multiply by œÄ and divide by 180¬∞.

_data.text: Radians are a different way to measure angles based on the circle's perimeter - 360 degrees are equal to 2œÄ radians. To convert degrees to radians, all you have to do is multiply by œÄ and divide by 180¬∞.

_data.name: Distance Between a Line and a Point

children.value: To get the formula for the distance between a point and a line, we need to use the properties of a triangle where the height is the distance between the line and the point and the other two vertices are the points of intersections of the line with X and Y axes.

_data.text: To get the formula for the distance between a point and a line, we need to use the properties of a triangle where the height is the distance between the line and the point and the other two vertices are the points of intersections of the line with X and Y axes.

children.value: The shortest segment which is a distance between two parallel lines is part of a line perpendicular to the two. We use this fact to find the general formula for coordinates of two points, where each of the points belongs to one of the parallel lines and the same perpendicular line. After that, we apply the
formula to find and apply the formula for distance between the two lines.

_data.text: The shortest segment which is a distance between two parallel lines is part of a line perpendicular to the two. We use this fact to find the general formula for coordinates of two points, where each of the points belongs to one of the parallel lines and the same perpendicular line. After that, we apply the [distance between points](distance_between_points) formula to find and apply the formula for distance between the two lines.

_data.name: Distance Between Points

children.value: To find the distance between two points, we first have to find the distance between the X coordinates (dx) and Y coordinates (dy) of the points. After that, we apply the Pythagorean theorem (dx and dy are the legs of a right triangle, and the distance between A and B is the hypotenuse) and evaluate the square root of the sum of dx squared and dy squared.

_data.text: To find the distance between two points, we first have to find the distance between the X coordinates (dx) and Y coordinates (dy) of the points. After that, we apply the Pythagorean theorem (dx and dy are the legs of a right triangle, and the distance between A and B is the hypotenuse) and evaluate the square root of the sum of dx squared and dy squared.

_data.name: Greatest Common Factor

children.value: For two numbers A and B, a common factor of A and B is a number C such that both A/C and B/C are natural numbers. The Greatest Common Factor (or Divisor) is the biggest C.

_data.text: For two numbers A and B, a common factor of A and B is a number C such that both A/C and B/C are natural numbers. The Greatest Common Factor (or Divisor) is the biggest C.

_data.name: Lowest Common Multiple

children.value:
For two numbers A and B, a common multiple of A and B is a number C such that both C/A and C/B are natural numbers. The Lowest (or Least, or Smallest) Common Multiple
is the smallest C.

To convert Cartesian coordinates to [polar coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_coordinate_system), we need to separately evaluate the radius *r* and the angle *Œ∏*. The radius is the same as the vector's length, so we just apply the [vector length](magnitude) formula to get it. To get *Œ∏*, we look for the angle whose tangent equals *y* over *x*.

In order to convert polar coordinates to Cartesian coordinates, think of *x*, *y* and *r* as the sides of a right triangle, where *r* is the hypotenuse. Use two trigonometric functions, cosine and sine, to find the values of *x* and *y* respectively.

*Side note: You may also use this as a point converter.*

I‚Äôve decided to write an ‚Äúarticle‚Äù on how I personally deal with organizing and planning my activities. I came up with this system by myself, so it might not work for everyone, yet I still decided to write about it. I hope someone finds this useful.
It‚Äôs quite a flexible concept, so you don‚Äôt have to apply everything at once to make it work. Feel free to take inspiration from this article.
Before we begin, I‚Äôve got to mention I came up with an entire terminology for this and I‚Äôll move from one term to another step-by-step.

The idea is that I divide life into a few ‚Äúthreads‚Äù which act as groups of certain activities. By activities, I mean repeatedly performed actions (such as playing a game, reading a book, or working on a project), but not habits we do automatically. In fact, Threads are categories of activities. Deciding what categories should these be is up to you; I have one thread for team projects, one for private projects, one for self-learning and one for playing games; occasionally some other appear from time to time.

Thread branches are simply the activities I talked about above. In a specific moment, each thread has a specific number of branches. It changes over time, and I log the changes in the so-called Threads Chronology.
A branch is considered to have joined a thread when a certain activity was started being performed and it is considered to have left on the day the activity was stopped being performed. I also call them active and inactive branches.
Apart from being active or inactive, a thread or branch can also be disabled, which means that it has been put in a state where nothing can be performed regarding it.

Stability is a concept I‚Äôve came up with much later and it isn‚Äôt as concrete. It‚Äôs a way of saying how far a thread or branch is from being inactive with respect to how often branches are planned to be performed but aren‚Äôt. An unstable thread or branch is closer to being inactive while a highly stable one means that the thread is prospering.
Stability is not measured precisely, although in fact doing so would be possible.

Each thread has its own influence regarding other threads. It is not measured by the number of branches a thread has; influence is a mixture of how often (approximately) a thread‚Äôs branches are performed and how important they are. It is in high portion the thread influence that I use to divide the timeline.

That‚Äôs how I called the time unit that bases mostly on thread influence. Basically, a period begins anytime a thread changes its position among other threads regarding their influence. For me, periods usually last about 1-3 weeks. I also name each of them and list them in the so-called Periods Chronology.
Recently, I‚Äôve started listing a small number of resolutions for each period. When it is obvious that most resolutions will fail, a period may be abandoned and a new one is started immediately.
Periods can also change regarding other events in the timeline which do or don‚Äôt affect thread branches‚Äô accessibility, such as a trip.

Acts are the most important of all time units. Each has its own name and a list of resolutions, which (for me) number between ten and twenty. Every act consists of multiple periods. Thus, periods are lower in the hierarchy and their resolutions have to be fairly close to those of the acts.
Unlike periods, acts are a bit more neutral regarding threads, although it is often the case that an act has a ‚Äúleading thread‚Äù. Even so, periods don‚Äôt always have the act‚Äôs leading thread as their own leading thread despite being subordinate to acts.
For me, acts often last about 5-8 months.

I never really plan when they are supposed to end (although I often make approximations); I often decide to start one (or prepare to start one) once there is a visible result of how well were the resolutions performed.

The third and most basic unit of time in my planning system is a single day. Each day has its own plan (or summary, if a plan wasn‚Äôt prepared), which consists of about 5-10 tasks. Most of the tasks concern thread branches, but obviously other tasks appear as well if they are necessary.
Alternative choice task ‚Äì a task that offers an alternative task which can be chosen to do instead. Sometimes there can be two as well, in this case one of the three has to be chosen;
Prior task ‚Äì a task that has to be completed regardless of anything;
‚ÄúIf possible‚Äù task ‚Äì in other words, a task that has to be complete only if there is more time;
Bonus task ‚Äì if all tasks are completed, there is a bonus task.
Sometimes tasks have time limits, although it‚Äôs not appropriate for every task. I‚Äôve got two ways of making time limits:
Absolute ‚Äì demands a task to be complete until a certain moment during the day;
Relative ‚Äì demands a task to be complete within a certain amount of time.
Recently, I‚Äôve added a bunch of new features to the planning system. Once a day is near its end, I write a short evaluation of the plan‚Äôs results and I rate my performance.
And, basically, that‚Äôs it. If you want, you can move further and read about how the system gradually formed in my mind.
This part may be less interesting for you as it mainly talks about how I ended up having this system and using Trello for applying the concept.

My first attempts to organize my time happened in 2018. On the last day of 2017, I‚Äôd created a list of 15 resolutions which I‚Äôd try to accomplish throughout 2018. I called them the New Year‚Äôs Eve Declaration. In early 2018 I‚Äôd come up with the idea of acts and named the first act as above.
Originally, I had a different system of organization. On January 3rd, upon my return from Masuria where I‚Äôve spent New Year‚Äôs Eve, I created the so-called Activity Log which would be the first log I‚Äôd use to track my progress throughout time. It relied on special rules upon which I had to accomplish tasks to gain points while I had to gain at least 1 point daily.

That system lasted over a year without much of a change, however in early 2019 I‚Äôve encountered more and more types of tasks that couldn‚Äôt be measured so easily ‚Äì for example, if 1 hour of learning a piano piece is worth one point, how much points would making a music piece be worth? It was March 2019 when my current system started taking a form.

In May 2018, I‚Äôve installed ColorNote and it served as the first app I used for organization. On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of.

In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later.

Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed.

Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing.

Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization.

Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board.
Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.

I came up with this system by myself, so it might not work for everyone, yet I still decided to write about it. I hope someone finds this useful. It‚Äôs quite a flexible concept, so you don‚Äôt have to apply everything at once to make it work. Feel free to take inspiration from this article.
**Table of Contents** 1. Organizing the activities 2. Ordering the timeline 3. Everyday planning 4. By activities, I mean repeatedly performed actions (such as playing a game, reading a book, or working on a project), but not habits we do automatically. Deciding what categories should these be is up to you; I have one thread for team projects, one for private projects, one for self-learning and one for playing games; occasionally some other appear from time to time. #### Branches Thread branches are simply the activities I talked about above. In a specific moment, each thread has a specific number of branches. It changes over time, and I log the changes in the so-called Threads Chronology. I also call them active and inactive branches. It‚Äôs a way of saying how far a thread or branch is from being inactive with respect to how often branches are planned to be performed but aren‚Äôt. An unstable thread or branch is closer to being inactive while a highly stable one means that the thread is prospering. Stability is not measured precisely, although in fact doing so would be possible. ### Ordering the timeline #### Influence Each thread has its own influence regarding other threads. It is not measured by the number of branches a thread has; influence is a mixture of how often (approximately) a thread‚Äôs branches are performed and how important they are. It is in high portion the thread influence that I use to divide the timeline. #### Periods That‚Äôs how I called the time unit that bases mostly on thread influence. Basically, a period begins anytime a thread changes its position among other threads regarding their influence. For me, periods usually last about 1-3 weeks. I also name each of them and list them in the so-called Periods Chronology. Recently, I‚Äôve started listing a small number of resolutions for each period. When it is obvious that most resolutions will fail, a period may be abandoned and a new one is started immediately. Each has its own name and a list of resolutions, which (for me) number between ten and twenty. Every act consists of multiple periods. Thus, periods are lower in the hierarchy and their resolutions have to be fairly close to those of the acts. Unlike periods, acts are a bit more neutral regarding threads, although it is often the case that an act has a ‚Äúleading thread‚Äù. Even so, periods don‚Äôt always have the act‚Äôs leading thread as their own leading thread despite being subordinate to acts. For me, acts often last about 5-8 months. I never really plan when they are supposed to end (although I often make approximations); I often decide to start one (or prepare to start one) once there is a visible result of how well were the resolutions performed. ### Everyday planning The third and most basic unit of time in my planning system is a single day. Each day has its own plan (or summary, if a plan wasn‚Äôt prepared), which consists of about 5-10 tasks. Most of the tasks concern thread branches, but obviously other tasks appear as well if they are necessary. #### Types of tasks 1. Normal task ‚Äì a simple task; 2. Alternative choice task ‚Äì a task that offers an alternative task which can be chosen to do instead. Sometimes there can be two as well, in this case one of the three has to be chosen; 3. Prior task ‚Äì a task that has to be completed regardless of anything; 4. ‚ÄúIf possible‚Äù task ‚Äì in other words, a task that has to be complete only if there is more time; 5. Bonus task ‚Äì if all tasks are completed, there is a bonus task. #### Time limits Sometimes tasks have time limits, although it‚Äôs not appropriate for every task. I‚Äôve got two ways of making time limits: 1. Absolute ‚Äì demands a task to be complete until a certain moment during the day; 2. Relative ‚Äì demands a task to be complete within a certain amount of time. #### Result & rating Recently, I‚Äôve added a bunch of new features to the planning system. Once a day is near its end, I write a short evaluation of the plan‚Äôs results and I rate my performance.

And, basically, that‚Äôs it. If you want, you can move further and read about how the system gradually formed in my mind.

### History of the system This part may be less interesting for you as it mainly talks about how I ended up having this system and using Trello for applying the concept. My first attempts to organize my time happened in 2018. On the last day of 2017, I‚Äôd created a list of 15 resolutions which I‚Äôd try to accomplish throughout 2018. I called them the New Year‚Äôs Eve Declaration. In early 2018 I‚Äôd come up with the idea of acts and named the first act as above. Originally, I had a different system of organization. On January 3rd, upon my return from Masuria where I‚Äôve spent New Year‚Äôs Eve, I created the so-called Activity Log which would be the first log I‚Äôd use to track my progress throughout time. It relied on special rules upon which I had to accomplish tasks to gain points while I had to gain at least 1 point daily. That system lasted over a year without much of a change, however in early 2019 I‚Äôve encountered more and more types of tasks that couldn‚Äôt be measured so easily ‚Äì for example, if 1 hour of learning a piano piece is worth one point, how much points would making a music piece be worth? It was March 2019 when my current system started taking a form. In May 2018, I‚Äôve installed ColorNote and it served as the first app I used for organization. On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of. In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later. Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed. Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing. Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization. Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board. Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.

children.value:
I‚Äôve decided to write an ‚Äúarticle‚Äù on how I personally deal with organizing and planning my activities. I came up with this system by myself, so it might not work for everyone, yet I still decided to write about it. I hope someone finds this useful.
It‚Äôs quite a flexible concept, so you don‚Äôt have to apply everything at once to make it work. Feel free to take inspiration from this article.
Before we begin, I‚Äôve got to mention I came up with an entire terminology for this and I‚Äôll move from one term to another step-by-step.

The idea is that I divide life into a few ‚Äúthreads‚Äù which act as groups of certain activities. By activities, I mean repeatedly performed actions (such as playing a game, reading a book, or working on a project), but not habits we do automatically. In fact, Threads are categories of activities. Deciding what categories should these be is up to you; I have one thread for team projects, one for private projects, one for self-learning and one for playing games; occasionally some other appear from time to time.

Thread branches are simply the activities I talked about above. In a specific moment, each thread has a specific number of branches. It changes over time, and I log the changes in the so-called Threads Chronology.
A branch is considered to have joined a thread when a certain activity was started being performed and it is considered to have left on the day the activity was stopped being performed. I also call them active and inactive branches.
Apart from being active or inactive, a thread or branch can also be disabled, which means that it has been put in a state where nothing can be performed regarding it.

Stability is a concept I‚Äôve came up with much later and it isn‚Äôt as concrete. It‚Äôs a way of saying how far a thread or branch is from being inactive with respect to how often branches are planned to be performed but aren‚Äôt. An unstable thread or branch is closer to being inactive while a highly stable one means that the thread is prospering.
Stability is not measured precisely, although in fact doing so would be possible.

Each thread has its own influence regarding other threads. It is not measured by the number of branches a thread has; influence is a mixture of how often (approximately) a thread‚Äôs branches are performed and how important they are. It is in high portion the thread influence that I use to divide the timeline.

That‚Äôs how I called the time unit that bases mostly on thread influence. Basically, a period begins anytime a thread changes its position among other threads regarding their influence. For me, periods usually last about 1-3 weeks. I also name each of them and list them in the so-called Periods Chronology.
Recently, I‚Äôve started listing a small number of resolutions for each period. When it is obvious that most resolutions will fail, a period may be abandoned and a new one is started immediately.
Periods can also change regarding other events in the timeline which do or don‚Äôt affect thread branches‚Äô accessibility, such as a trip.

Acts are the most important of all time units. Each has its own name and a list of resolutions, which (for me) number between ten and twenty. Every act consists of multiple periods. Thus, periods are lower in the hierarchy and their resolutions have to be fairly close to those of the acts.
Unlike periods, acts are a bit more neutral regarding threads, although it is often the case that an act has a ‚Äúleading thread‚Äù. Even so, periods don‚Äôt always have the act‚Äôs leading thread as their own leading thread despite being subordinate to acts.
For me, acts often last about 5-8 months.

I never really plan when they are supposed to end (although I often make approximations); I often decide to start one (or prepare to start one) once there is a visible result of how well were the resolutions performed.

The third and most basic unit of time in my planning system is a single day. Each day has its own plan (or summary, if a plan wasn‚Äôt prepared), which consists of about 5-10 tasks. Most of the tasks concern thread branches, but obviously other tasks appear as well if they are necessary.
Alternative choice task ‚Äì a task that offers an alternative task which can be chosen to do instead. Sometimes there can be two as well, in this case one of the three has to be chosen;
Prior task ‚Äì a task that has to be completed regardless of anything;
‚ÄúIf possible‚Äù task ‚Äì in other words, a task that has to be complete only if there is more time;
Bonus task ‚Äì if all tasks are completed, there is a bonus task.
Sometimes tasks have time limits, although it‚Äôs not appropriate for every task. I‚Äôve got two ways of making time limits:
Absolute ‚Äì demands a task to be complete until a certain moment during the day;
Relative ‚Äì demands a task to be complete within a certain amount of time.
Recently, I‚Äôve added a bunch of new features to the planning system. Once a day is near its end, I write a short evaluation of the plan‚Äôs results and I rate my performance.
And, basically, that‚Äôs it. If you want, you can move further and read about how the system gradually formed in my mind.
This part may be less interesting for you as it mainly talks about how I ended up having this system and using Trello for applying the concept.

My first attempts to organize my time happened in 2018. On the last day of 2017, I‚Äôd created a list of 15 resolutions which I‚Äôd try to accomplish throughout 2018. I called them the New Year‚Äôs Eve Declaration. In early 2018 I‚Äôd come up with the idea of acts and named the first act as above.
Originally, I had a different system of organization. On January 3rd, upon my return from Masuria where I‚Äôve spent New Year‚Äôs Eve, I created the so-called Activity Log which would be the first log I‚Äôd use to track my progress throughout time. It relied on special rules upon which I had to accomplish tasks to gain points while I had to gain at least 1 point daily.

That system lasted over a year without much of a change, however in early 2019 I‚Äôve encountered more and more types of tasks that couldn‚Äôt be measured so easily ‚Äì for example, if 1 hour of learning a piano piece is worth one point, how much points would making a music piece be worth? It was March 2019 when my current system started taking a form.

In May 2018, I‚Äôve installed ColorNote and it served as the first app I used for organization. On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of.

In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later.

Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed.

Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing.

Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization.

Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board.
Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.

_data.text:
## My organization & planning system I‚Äôve decided to write an ‚Äúarticle‚Äù on how I personally deal with organizing and planning my activities. I came up with this system by myself, so it might not work for everyone, yet I still decided to write about it. I hope someone finds this useful. It‚Äôs quite a flexible concept, so you don‚Äôt have to apply everything at once to make it work. Feel free to take inspiration from this article.
**Table of Contents** 1. Organizing the activities 2. Ordering the timeline 3. Everyday planning 4. History of the system ### Organizing the activities Before we begin, I‚Äôve got to mention I came up with an entire terminology for this and I‚Äôll move from one term to another step-by-step. #### Threads The idea is that I divide life into a few ‚Äúthreads‚Äù which act as groups of certain activities. By activities, I mean repeatedly performed actions (such as playing a game, reading a book, or working on a project), but not habits we do automatically. In fact, Threads are categories of activities. Deciding what categories should these be is up to you; I have one thread for team projects, one for private projects, one for self-learning and one for playing games; occasionally some other appear from time to time. #### Branches Thread branches are simply the activities I talked about above. In a specific moment, each thread has a specific number of branches. It changes over time, and I log the changes in the so-called Threads Chronology. A branch is considered to have joined a thread when a certain activity was started being performed and it is considered to have left on the day the activity was stopped being performed. I also call them active and inactive branches. Apart from being active or inactive, a thread or branch can also be disabled, which means that it has been put in a state where nothing can be performed regarding it. #### Stability Stability is a concept I‚Äôve came up with much later and it isn‚Äôt as concrete. It‚Äôs a way of saying how far a thread or branch is from being inactive with respect to how often branches are planned to be performed but aren‚Äôt. An unstable thread or branch is closer to being inactive while a highly stable one means that the thread is prospering. Stability is not measured precisely, although in fact doing so would be possible. ### Ordering the timeline #### Influence Each thread has its own influence regarding other threads. It is not measured by the number of branches a thread has; influence is a mixture of how often (approximately) a thread‚Äôs branches are performed and how important they are. It is in high portion the thread influence that I use to divide the timeline. #### Periods That‚Äôs how I called the time unit that bases mostly on thread influence. Basically, a period begins anytime a thread changes its position among other threads regarding their influence. For me, periods usually last about 1-3 weeks. I also name each of them and list them in the so-called Periods Chronology. Recently, I‚Äôve started listing a small number of resolutions for each period. When it is obvious that most resolutions will fail, a period may be abandoned and a new one is started immediately. Periods can also change regarding other events in the timeline which do or don‚Äôt affect thread branches‚Äô accessibility, such as a trip. #### Acts Acts are the most important of all time units. Each has its own name and a list of resolutions, which (for me) number between ten and twenty. Every act consists of multiple periods. Thus, periods are lower in the hierarchy and their resolutions have to be fairly close to those of the acts. Unlike periods, acts are a bit more neutral regarding threads, although it is often the case that an act has a ‚Äúleading thread‚Äù. Even so, periods don‚Äôt always have the act‚Äôs leading thread as their own leading thread despite being subordinate to acts. For me, acts often last about 5-8 months. I never really plan when they are supposed to end (although I often make approximations); I often decide to start one (or prepare to start one) once there is a visible result of how well were the resolutions performed. ### Everyday planning The third and most basic unit of time in my planning system is a single day. Each day has its own plan (or summary, if a plan wasn‚Äôt prepared), which consists of about 5-10 tasks. Most of the tasks concern thread branches, but obviously other tasks appear as well if they are necessary. #### Types of tasks 1. Normal task ‚Äì a simple task; 2. Alternative choice task ‚Äì a task that offers an alternative task which can be chosen to do instead. Sometimes there can be two as well, in this case one of the three has to be chosen; 3. Prior task ‚Äì a task that has to be completed regardless of anything; 4. ‚ÄúIf possible‚Äù task ‚Äì in other words, a task that has to be complete only if there is more time; 5. Bonus task ‚Äì if all tasks are completed, there is a bonus task. #### Time limits Sometimes tasks have time limits, although it‚Äôs not appropriate for every task. I‚Äôve got two ways of making time limits: 1. Absolute ‚Äì demands a task to be complete until a certain moment during the day; 2. Relative ‚Äì demands a task to be complete within a certain amount of time. #### Result & rating Recently, I‚Äôve added a bunch of new features to the planning system. Once a day is near its end, I write a short evaluation of the plan‚Äôs results and I rate my performance.

And, basically, that‚Äôs it. If you want, you can move further and read about how the system gradually formed in my mind.

### History of the system This part may be less interesting for you as it mainly talks about how I ended up having this system and using Trello for applying the concept. My first attempts to organize my time happened in 2018. On the last day of 2017, I‚Äôd created a list of 15 resolutions which I‚Äôd try to accomplish throughout 2018. I called them the New Year‚Äôs Eve Declaration. In early 2018 I‚Äôd come up with the idea of acts and named the first act as above. Originally, I had a different system of organization. On January 3rd, upon my return from Masuria where I‚Äôve spent New Year‚Äôs Eve, I created the so-called Activity Log which would be the first log I‚Äôd use to track my progress throughout time. It relied on special rules upon which I had to accomplish tasks to gain points while I had to gain at least 1 point daily. That system lasted over a year without much of a change, however in early 2019 I‚Äôve encountered more and more types of tasks that couldn‚Äôt be measured so easily ‚Äì for example, if 1 hour of learning a piano piece is worth one point, how much points would making a music piece be worth? It was March 2019 when my current system started taking a form. In May 2018, I‚Äôve installed ColorNote and it served as the first app I used for organization. On March 24th, 2019, I‚Äôve created the first plan, then called a ‚ÄúTo-do List‚Äù. Three more would appear that month and in April it turned into daily planning. Meanwhile, a new logging system has also appeared. On March 27th, I faced a few trivial events which couldn‚Äôt appear in Activity Log and therefore I created the Trivia Log for random events I might one day want to know the date of. In late August 2018 I would come up with the concept of Threads for the first time. It returned in March 2019, and on the 19th I would create the Threads Chronology I mentioned above. The idea of periods followed in April and Periods Chronology appeared a month after the Threads one, although I‚Äôd come up with the name about a year later. Activity Log would still function back then, but it wasn‚Äôt changing and in June 2019 it came to me that it has to be stopped. It would still be used without the ‚Äú1 point every day‚Äù rule until the end of 2019 when it was turned off completely.
The next changes in the system would mainly involve the device and service I used for it, as the ideas from 2019 formed a steady base of the system and didn‚Äôt need to be changed. Originally I‚Äôd organize and plan everything in ColorNote, which I used on my tablet, however by the end of 2019 I‚Äôve switched to my phone and ColorNote became increasingly uncomfortable, mainly due to its little capabilities. By middle 2020 my game dev team would start developing our own app for organization called Orderer and on 12-14th July I would move to that app. However, for now only the computer version existed while I wanted both (ColorNote, on the other hand, wasn‚Äôt available for Linux). And it wasn‚Äôt the only problem. Although the app had the features ColorNote lacked (except planning, which I still had to do in ColorNote), they still weren‚Äôt comfortable in use and the team had little time to work on the app as we had other important projects ongoing. Eventually, I‚Äôd move from Orderer to Atom which allowed for a more comfortable use, but I still had to plan in ColorNote which kept my organization separated into parts between the computer and the phone. Finally, BeetMacol would find Trello and offered to move all of our team to-do lists there. At first I wasn‚Äôt sure, but once I explored the capabilities of Trello, I didn‚Äôt just agree to move the team to-do lists there ‚Äì I‚Äôve also created private board for my organization. Here, I‚Äôve quite much decided to start anew; the way Trello worked didn‚Äôt allow me to simply copy all my to-do lists there. Instead, I‚Äôve created a new style of organization compatible with Trello which I would continuously improve over time and add more and more stuff into it. The acts, which would previously be organized in a document on my computer, also became one of the lists further on my ‚ÄúHeadquarters‚Äù Trello board which mainly features tasks categorized into the lists ‚ÄúMath‚Äù, ‚ÄúMusic‚Äù, ‚ÄúPiano‚Äù, ‚ÄúReading‚Äù, ‚ÄúWritten works‚Äù, ‚ÄúOther‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAll-time Delayed To-do‚Äù, last of which was a set of less important tasks I didn‚Äôt have time on (which I created all the way back in 2018). On the left, the board has a separate list where I put completed tasks, and on the right there is a list of canceled tasks. Further on the right are separate lists for Periods, Operations and Acts which are kind of detached from the rest of the board. Again, I hope you find some of this useful or a source of inspiration.
